Chief Complaint:
MEG pain
History of Present Illness:
Susan Meis is a 61 year old female with a history of reflux, hypothyroidism, constipation,
records reviewed
-3/21/2024 EGD/colonoscopy: EGD- + Eosinophilic Esophagitis. Minimal chronic gastritis, +fundic gland polyps, Duodenal biopsies normal. (TTG was positive) COLON: diverticulosis in sigmoid colon, IH o/w normal
-8/11/2025 Labs: CBC, CMP- normal, CMP
-8/12/2025 Abdominal US: + gallstones
Today patient states that for the last 2 months she is having issues with abdominal pain/burning she states that when she eats she gets abdominal pain, she is currently on Omeprazole 40 mg BID as well as Pepcid 20 mg BID and still reports some breakthrough symptoms. she also reports some intermittent dysphagia that usually happens with rice, chicken and raw carrots. she uses 2 capfuls daily of miralax (at times she can use 3 capfuls) and is able to have a BM daily that is soft stool, denies any blood with her BMs, denies any black tarry stool, denies any lower abdominal or rectal pain. she is due for a colonoscopy and would like to add on a EGD at the same time. GI ROS otherwise negative or noncontributory.

Assessment:
for the last 2 months she is having issues with abdominal pain/burning she states that when she eats she gets abdominal pain, she is currently on Omeprazole 40 mg BID as well as Pepcid 20 mg BID and still reports some breakthrough symptoms. she also reports some intermittent dysphagia that usually happens with rice, chicken and raw carrots. she uses 2 capfuls daily of miralax (at times she can use 3 capfuls) and is able to have a BM daily that is soft stool, denies any blood with her BMs, denies any black tarry stool, denies any lower abdominal or rectal pain. she is due for a colonoscopy and would like to add on a EGD at the same time.
-continue current medication
-GERD diet
-trial carafate
-schedule EGD/colonoscopy-- suflave (pt has prep already at home)
-refer to Dr Cione for gallstones and RUQ abdominal pain
Plan:
omeprazole 40 mg Take 1 capsule by mouth twice a day, 30 minutes before meals
Continue current medications
Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
sucralfate 1 gram Take 1 tablet by mouth four times a day, crush mix with 2 tbsp water
EGD/Colonoscopy with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43235/45378-- suflave
refer to Dr Cione

Chief Complaint:
gastroparesis, follow up
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 74-year-old female here for follow-up on her gastroparesis. Of note she was also inpatient at THR Denton from 9/6/2025 to 9/7/2025. She presented to the ER for evaluation of her chest pain and was found to be in hypertensive urgency and uncontrolled hypertension. She also had CT of her abdomen and pelvis in the emergency room which showed mild sigmoid diverticulitis or colitis she had no symptoms of abdominal pain diarrhea fever and WBC count was normal, likely mild sigmoid diverticulitis. She was initiated on antibacterial therapy with Augmentin x 5 days. Last colonoscopy was 4 years ago 8/16/2021 that showed diverticulosis of the sigmoid colon. She was recommended to follow-up with our office regarding her recent diverticulitis diagnosis.
CT abdomen pelvis 9/6/2025: Mild sigmoid diverticulitis or colitis findings with small amount of free pelvic fluid without bowel obstruction no pneumoperitoneum and normal appendix. Mild bibasilar pneumonia or atelectasis with very mild right sided pleural effusion. Fatty liver. Severe fatty atrophy of pancreas. Status postcholecystectomy with surgical clips at gallbladder fossa.
Labs 9/9/2025: WBC 2.8, Hgb 10.6, HCT 33.3, PLT 200, MCV 95.7 normal liver enzymes hemoglobin A1c 5.7
Past Medical History
Medications:
amoxicillin 875 mg Take 2 tablets by mouth twice a day as directed for 10 days

Assessment:
Patient is a 74-year-old white female here accompanied by her husband for follow-up visit today. Patient has history of gastroparesis and chronic constipation. She recently had L4-L5 disc surgery with Dr. Catino on 7/9/25. She has history of chronic A-fib, breast cancer, type II DM, HTN, HLD, OSA, she has internal loop recorder and several previous ablations for recurrent her A-fib.
Patient reports that on Saturday she developed chest pain and presented to THR Denton for evaluation where she was admitted until 9/8/2025. She was treated for uncontrolled hypertension as well as CT of the abdomen and pelvis which revealed mild sigmoid diverticulitis or colitis. She was discharged home on Augmentin for 5 days. She reports that during her ER visit she was not having any abdominal pain, no diarrhea and no fever. We discussed that she has a history of diverticulosis on her last colonoscopy in 2021 and potential for development of diverticulitis. Patient states prior to ER visit and since being home she is more constipated. She states that due to her recent back surgery, pain medications, decreased mobility she has been having constipation and only having a bowel movement every 3 days. We discussed bowel regimen today to include MiraLAX and Benefiber. We also discussed need for colonoscopy in 8 weeks from her first episode of diverticulitis. Due to her recent back surgery and the fact that she has not been released for PT yet we will call the patient in a month and get an update on her symptoms.The goal would be to complete a colonoscopy in 8 weeks however this timeframe may need to be adjusted due to her mobility.
Patient and husband in agreement today no concerns, ER precautions reviewed.
Plan:
Recall in to call pt in 1 month with goal of colonscopy in 8 wks from today due to recent diverticulitis episode.
Follow-up with PCP for elevated blood pressure reading*
Diverticulitis, patient education materials generated by EMR
Gradual titration of fiber supplementation discussed (Benefiber, Metamucil, Citrucel.)
Miralax titration recommended

Chief Complaint:
Dysphagia
History of Present Illness:
Albert Aucoin is a 89 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Last seen here in January 2023. Here with recent food impaction. He was eating grits, bacon and cold milk. He began to have the hiccups while eating. He could not throw up, he couldn't eat or drink anything during that time. The food impaction stayed for 4 hours and was about to go to the ER. His son give him a cup of hot water and with this, he was able to get the good to go down. This was Thursday of last week. He has been able to eat/drink since then with no issues. He has had hiccups twice while eating and was able to go throw up since last seen here in 2023. This most recent occurrence he was unable to throw up or even swallow his saliva. He did require dilation x2 in 2016 and states he did respond to dilation at that time. He has not been on Nexium for some time now.
No lower GI complaints or unintentional weight loss.

Follow up 4-6 weeks
Avoid swallowing large pieces of food, dry bread, especially meat. Wash pills down with plenty of fluids.

Reflux
History of Present Illness:
Sally Breaux is a 82 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. She has chronic regurgitation sometimes in the morning, sometimes at noon. She remains on Dexilant once daily and recently started Pepcid at bedtime.
She has issues with mainly liquids and is only if she drinks liquids alone. She has no solid food dysphagia.  Denies coughing or choking with liquids.
She had an EGD in April 2025 with findings reviewed. She does have thyroid disease and is on meds. she is not a diabetic. She has never had GES but does not want Reglan. She did not feel like low residue diet helped her symptoms.
She has no abdominal pain, bowel changes on overt GI bleeding. History of fundoplication in 2019. She does not want to have another surgery at her age so is not interested in seeing surgeon for revision.

Currently on Dexilant and Pepcid at bedtime. Regurgitation persists but has not been progressive. Discussed trial of Voquenza and will plan for esophagram for evaluation of her esophageal motility.
Plan:
Voquenza 10mg samples-- start with 1 daily in AM. Hold the Dexilant while taking this. Try to hold the afternoon Pepcid but okay to take the Pepcid with supper if you feel you need it.
Barium Swallow (Esophagram) WITH tablet - 74220
Patient to call office in 2 weeks.

Chief Complaint:
check up-3 month
History of Present Illness:
Peggy Leblanc is a 75 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Last visit 06/24/2025. She presents today with chronic epigastric pain, SBO in November/December (on a background of narcotics, RSV, and GLP-1 use) which required 5 days hospitalization at Terrebonne with conservative treatment, and chronic constipation. Recent UGI with SBFT - reviewed with patient and husband today. Long term history of GERD which is under control with esomeprazole BID. She has been unable to tolerate skipping a dose of this in the past without rebound symptoms. Denies nausea, vomiting since bowel obstruction and discontinuing GLP-1 use. Denies dysphagia. She can have rare/intermittent mild epigastric discomfort described as a bloating discomfort. Belching and Dr Pepper intake resolves this. She is currently taking stool softener/MiraLAX daily and has daily bowel movements. Denies straining, frequent diarrhea, overt GI bleeding. Her weight is stable since last visit here but she did gain 10 pounds back with discontinuation of GLP-1. She is on baby aspirin, celebrex and cilostazol. Denies other NSAID use. She has chronic back pain and has pain pump with dilaudid since the 1990s. EGD x 2 in 2024 - incomplete due to food in stomach (she was on GLP-1 at this time). NGES 8/2024 ok. Last CT 6/2025. Prior CT 11/2024. She has had colonoscopies with Dr Birriel which was normal and up to date and recommendations to repeat in 10 years (which she reports will be when she is older than 80 and will not be interested) - no records. Recent diagnosis of emphysema with Dr Patten and she has inhalers for PRN use. She continues to follow Dr Arora at CIS in Thibodaux. DM is most under control right now with restarting metformin. She used to smoke, quit in 2006. Denies alcohol use. Long term history of chronic anemia - details are not exactly clear. She still has her gallbladder - remote history of gallbladder workup years ago.

Assessment:
Current colorectal cancer screening and surveillance guidelines discussed with the patient during today's clinic visit. Personal family history of colon polyps. If adenomas are detected, repeat colonoscopy would be determined by pathology as well as size and number of polyps for surveillance interval in 3-7 year range. Will provide further recommendations after colonoscopy.
Plan:
Colonoscopy with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 45378
Risks and benefits statement: The procedure and its preparation, benefits, alternatives, and limitations were explained to the patient or legal guardian. The risks and potential complications including but not limited to perforation, bleeding, infection, missed lesion, aspiration and other complications of sedation were reviewed. The patient or legal guardian verbalized understanding and wishes to proceed.
Initiate pre-procedure orders per facility protocol.
Suflave 178.7-7.3-0.5 gram Drink 1 bottle by mouth, twice a day, split dose per prep instructions
Hold Wegovy (semaglutide) for 10 days prior to procedure.
Hold fish oil for 5 days prior to procedure

Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
Follow-up with me in 6 months

- decreased gluten 25%

Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain, change in bowel habits, diarrhea,burping
History of Present Illness:
Patient is seen in the office after she had an episode of diarrhea that lasted for 2 days with some abdominal pain and cramping. Symptoms have since subsided and she feels well. She has had a history of irritable bowel syndrome that responds well to dicyclomine. Remote history of microscopic colitis but colonoscopy done back in 2021 was normal. Feels well otherwise and is able to tolerate a regular diet
PAST SUMMARIES
Feels well except for irritable bowel syndrome symptoms that is helped with the use of dicyclomine. She has been treated for splenic lymphoma appears to be in remission. Complains of heartburn and indigestion early in the morning without any nausea vomiting or dysphagia.
PAST REVIEWS;
Peggy Pickett  is a 82 year old   female  who is seen today for a follow-up visit.
Pt presents for a follow-up after developing diarrhea, abdominal bloating, discomfort as well as early satiety after 2 bouts of antibiotics. She had 1 course of nitrofurantoin starting back in August 11, 2023 and then she had a course of Bactrim starting November 11, 2023 for a UTI. After the first course of antibiotics she began developing epigastric discomfort, lower abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, belching, and intermittent diarrhea and constipation. She was tested for C. difficile on November 28 and was negative for infection. She notes that in the last 6 weeks she has been having alternating periods of diarrhea and constipation. She is currently experiencing more diarrhea, with 3 episodes of diarrhea yesterday. This is improved when she takes the dicyclomine twice a day. If she takes more than that she does feel dizzy and sleepy. She does not note any blood in her stool. Her last colonoscopy was back in 2021 that was remarkable for diverticulosis. In 2018 she did have an inflammatory polyp as well as changes suggestive of ischemic colitis which was negative for obstruction on CT angiogram. She also has a history of segmental colitis in 2018 and developed post colitis IBS. She did have C. difficile in the past for which she noted similar symptoms which is why we tested her. She presents with her daughter.
FOLLOW UP JULY 2022';
Patient is seen in the office with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain diarrhea nausea and some bloating.Patient is here for follow-up. She had some recent blood work which is within normal limits and takes dicyclomine and Imodium as needed. Colonoscopy done last year showed evidence of diverticulosis but no microscopic colitis. No systemic symptoms.
PAST SUMMARIES;
Peggy Pickett  is a 80 year old   female  who is seen today for a follow-up visit.  Patient is seen in the office after recent colonoscopy and biopsies that were normal without any evidence of microscopic colitis.  She has intermittent spells of diarrhea that seems to respond to dicyclomine.PAST SUMMARIES JULY 2021 Patient was seen in the office with a 6-week history of diarrhea about 5-6 times a day without much improvement with the usual medicines that he takes namely the dicyclomine and the Imodium. She had a history of segmental colitis in 2018 thereafter she developed post colitis irritable bowel syndrome that was well controlled. Denies any hematochezia melena or other systemic symptoms. PAST SUMMARIES MAY 2021 Peggy Pickett is a 79 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.Feels well except for IBS type diarrhea off and on relieved by imodium. Post PET scan showed lymphoma in remission.PAST SUMMARY; The patient feels well after her recent colonoscopy without any further symptoms of diarrhea or bleeding. Colonoscopy showed some benign inflammatory polyp as well as patchy segmental colitis. Biopsies were suggestive of ischemic colitis. She is currently to be scheduled for a CT angiogram to assess patency of the mesenteric vasculature.PAST SUMMARIES; The patient presented with a one-day history of hematochezia that lasted for one episode. This is associated with lower abdominal pain and cramping and some low-grade fever, no nausea or vomiting. Patient had a previous history of Clostridium difficile colitis in the remote past as well as ischemic colitis. Denies any antibiotic use of any medications at this time. PAST SUMMARIES;PEGGY PICKETT is seen today for a follow-up visit. Recent recurrent diarrhea / cramps with a food bar, bettr on dicyclomine. PAST SUMMARY; History of Present Illness PEGGY PICKETT is seen today for a follow-up visit. The patient is seen in the office on reason CT angiogram which showed no evidence of mesenteric ischemia. Previous colonoscopy and showed evidence of findings suggestive of ischemic colitis. The clinical symptoms and signs consistent with infectious etiology. Small incidental saccular aneurysms were noted in the splenic artery. She is otherwise asymptomatic feels well without any complaints. Symptoms of bleeding abdominal pain mostly resolve

Chief Complaint:
(832) 720-9267-3m f/u, pt had to stop taking her wegovy due to vomiting and diarrhea,
History of Present Illness:
Jenna Boone is a 29 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.In today's patient visit, Jenna Boon, a 29-year-old female with a history of ulcerative colitis treated with Entyvio infusions and post-pregnancy obesity, presented for a follow-up consultation via telehealth video conference. The primary concern was the management of Wegovy. She had been taking Wegovy for weight loss and successfully lost over 50 pounds. However, after her dose was increased to the highest level, 2.7 mg, she developed significant nausea and diarrhea, prompting her to discontinue the medication under the guidance of her primary care provider.
The patient expressed a desire to restart Wegovy as she felt it was very effective not only for weight loss but also observed that her acne, which had improved while on the medication, has returned since cessation. She also reports the return of "food noise" and acknowledges she is under significant stress due to family matters, which could also be a contributing factor to her acne. Her ulcerative colitis is quiescent, and she denies any bleeding or diarrhea related to it. Her last Entyvio infusion was recent, and the next one is scheduled for 09/16/2025.
Her previous primary care provider has left the practice, and she is scheduled to see a new nurse practitioner, Jancy Cherian, on 09/23/2025.

- Ulcerative Colitis: The condition is currently in remission with Entyvio infusions. There are no active symptoms such as bleeding or diarrhea.
- Obesity/Wegovy Management: The patient experienced significant weight loss with Wegovy but developed intolerable gastrointestinal side effects at the highest dose. Given the benefits, it is reasonable to attempt re-initiation of the medication. It has been agreed to restart at the initial low dose and titrate up gradually as tolerated. She was counseled that this approach is necessary due to being off the medication for several weeks. A note will be sent to her new primary care provider, Jancy Cherian, NP, to communicate this recommendation.
- Laboratory Evaluation: To monitor her underlying inflammatory bowel disease, inflammatory markers will be checked via blood and stool testing.

It is recommended to restart Wegovy at the lowest initial dose and titrate upwards slowly as tolerated.

Chief Complaint:
1 year follow up, hemorrhoids
History of Present Illness:
Jana Hehs is a 62 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.
This is a patient we see for GERD. Als has personal history of colon polyps. Last seen June 2024 by Dr. McMyler.
Her EGD in 2023 showed LA grade a esophagitis and we started her on omeprazole 20 mg once a day in the morning for 60 days with famotidine 40 mg at bedtime. Her symptoms did improve with the Omeprazole 20mg, but she does not want to be on a PPI due to the history of osteopenia. She was continued on Famotidine 40mg daily. Noted has previously taken Nexium. In the past had worked on diet and lifestyle modifications and weight loss to improve her symptoms (cut out Dr Pepper and fried foods etc). She has history of a lot of phlegm and mucus in her throat and was to see ENT in the past.
Reviewed outside records. She was seen at Methodist Bulverde ER 6/29/2025 diarrhea x 1 month CT scan with enterocolitis 5.9 cm left pelvic mass WBC 11.5 Was given Azithromycin. She has been having intermittent issues with hemorrhoids and rectal bleeding and has tried various OTC products without benefit.
Currently, patient reports she has been dealing with hemorrhoid issues for a few months now.  Says after the first of the year had some greasy/oily stools and thought maybe was related to holiday diet.  Says by March was eating better and walking and increasing physical actiivity but in mid-april or beginning of May started having diarrhea. Then June 29th ended up in the ER and was diagnosed with colitis.  Was treated with abx and her diarrhea stopped and bowels went back to normal. But still had a lot of hemorrhoid irritation with burning and blood on tissue with wiping.  Symptoms worse with walking exercise and having worse bleeding.  She started to wonder if maybe she has anal fissure rather than hemorrhoid since usually her hemorrhoids eventually go away.  Has tried various OTC products without much benefit.  Says is having issue with pieces of stool getting stuck in the rectum and having to wipe several times with wet toilet paper and then sits in the tub. Having about 3 bowel movements per day and are rough and dry. Says it feels like a papercut at her rectum after bowel movements.  Is not on fiber supplement or Miralax.
Review of records
--EGD/colonoscopy 7/28/2016 1. EGD--Inflammation and a small break was noted at the GEJ c/w reflux esophagitis., Biopsies taken from the stomach were negative for H.Pylori, Erythema was noted in the duodenum bulb c/w duodenitis. Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain, bloating
History of Present Illness:
Daniel is a pleasant 56-year-old male who presents for evaluation of abdominal pain and bloating. His history includes tirzepatide and metformin but discontinued use of these around 3 months ago. He stopped these medications as he felt these led to his symptoms. He is complaining of a "stitch" on his right upper quadrant. He describes this as similar to an exercise cramp but it is constantly there. He denies aggravators or alleviators. He is reporting constant abdominal bloating. He typically has regular bowel movements but when eating poorly his stools will become loose. Denies melena or hematochezia. He notes chronic acid reflux and uses Pepcid or Tums as needed. Again his heartburn is present when his diet is poor. Denies dysphagia, nausea or vomiting. He does consume 3 Cokes per day, admits to moderate sugar and carbohydrate intake without much fiber or protein. He is aware about his dietary choices are likely contributing to his symptoms. He comes with a normal CBC and a GI Map performed by SALT Health and has an appointment with them later this week to discuss results. Stool test was performed back in June when he was having diarrhea. At that time he was positive for Campylobacter and Shiga like toxin E. coli with elevated commensal bacteria and opportunistic microbes. He had a normal elastase and antigliadin IgAwith a fecal calprotectin of 167. His most recent colonoscopy in 2019 with removal of 1 sigmoid tubular adenoma.

Assessment:
He presents for evaluation of abdominal pain and bloating. He has not had any workup for his symptoms other than his GI Map. This suggests bacterial overgrowth and his symptoms are consistent with IBS-D so we will have him complete a course of Xifaxan. He is aware that his diet is not the best and he consumes highly fermentable items, strongly encouraged low FODMAP including eliminating his soda intake. He is due for colonoscopy due to his history of adenomatous colon polyps we will get him scheduled for that. He also has chronic acid reflux now with right upper quadrant pain so we will schedule EGD to rule out evidence of peptic ulcer disease, H. pylori, celiac disease, Barrett's or other pathology. We will obtain liver enzymes on him today and get him scheduled for ultrasound for hepatobiliary assessment.Further recommendations will be given post.

Diagnosis:
Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea
Family history of colon cancer in mother
Assessment:
1. IBS-D: We discussed the pathophysiology and natural history of irritable bowel syndrome. We discussed the ROME IV criteria which the patient meets; I suspect IBS-D pre-dominant disease. We discussed the implications of diet, the brain-gut interaction/visceral hypersensitivity, and dysbiosis on the manifestation of symptoms and guiding treatment options. Other considerations include SIBO/IMO and functional bowel disorders which can have a similar presentation. Will plan to optimize the patient's bowel regimen with anti-spasmodics, IBGard and dicyclomine, as needed for abdominal pain. I have also provided information on a low FODMAP diet which has been studied in patients with IBS. Will plan to obtain a H.pylori, SIBO breath test, TSH and celiac panel with consideration for further testing including colonoscopy and breath testing based on symptoms/response to treatment. We discussed the role of neuromodulators (ie. TCA v. SSRI) as well which we can be considered in the future. Will provide a course of Xifaxan to start after SIBO testing performed since she is going to Morocco in October for vacation and is very worried that she won't be able to enjoy due to her GI sx.
Plan:
Low FODMAP diet basic, patient education materials generated by EMR
Gradual titration of fiber supplementation discussed (Citrucel 1-2 tabs/daily.)
H. pylori, Urea Breath Test (UBT)
Celiac Ab profile: tTg IgG/IgA, DGP IgG/IgA, total IgA
TSH with reflex to T4

Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
History of Present Illness:
Jennifer Sanchez is a 49 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.
This is a patient we see for IBS. Last seen April 2024 by Dr. McMyler.
Has IBS and chronic abdominal pain. Fructose and lactose malabsorption test were negative. Colonoscopy was essentially normal in 2019. KUB 2019 revealed moderate colonic stool burden. She reported in May 2023 started daily exercising and intermittent fasting. Noted the exercise did help with the pain and she would pass gas when she was walking. She did try MiraLAX and had soft stools but she is unsure if she took it long enough. States when she passes the stool then she has increased abdominal pain. Once the stools pass her pain does improve. Peppermint oil does aid with her symptoms and uses it topically. Has previously been prescribed a trial of duloxetine 30 mg once a day but patient never tried it states she has been exercising and taking magnesium 500 mg 1-2 tabs a day and having a bowel movement once a day. Still has pain and bloating but it has improved and usually worsens around her cycle.
Currently, patient reports that she has a pain in the LUQ and thought maybe she strained a muscle with working out.  Started a couple weeks ago.  Went to urgent care on Friday and had an abdominal xray and was told it was normal.  Says the pain is sharp and worse with movement such as twisting or bending.   The pain does improve with Advil.  Has been alternating ice and heating pad as well. No shingles rash.  Has tried to modify her kettle bell swings. Pain does not worsen with deep inspiration. Says the past year has been crazy with her IBS and having some increased gas pain and has more pain with fluctuation of her hormones.  Is having a  BM once a day.  But has a lot of bloating and does sleep with a heating pad.   No nausea or vomiting.  Is having a lot of heartburn and belching recently but not taking anything for this.

EPIGASTRIC PAIN: here for mid epigastric pain. Discussed dietary modifications and treatment options in detail. The differential of the pain does include GERD, peptic ulcer disease, dyspepsia, gastritis, gastric outlet obstruction, mass, infection, and possibly biliary issues as well.
CONSTIPATION: here with constipation and change in bowel habits. Discussed dietary modifications and treatment options in detail. The differential includes gastroparesis, Crohns, colonic obstruction, diverticulosis, intestinal motility issues, megacolon, and endocrine disorders.
GERD: We discussed a GERD diet in detail, patient should avoid trigger foods, avoid late meals, and elevate the head of the bed. Handout available to patient.
The recent changes of GERD, mild constipation and epigastric pain could be very well related to the new dietary restriction (1 meal/day);
will start with HP breath test and empiric PPI therapy and GERD diet

Dear Dr. Mistry, I had the wonderful pleasure of meeting Brenda today who as you know is a 34yo WF who is being referred for evaluation and management of ~20 year history of gradual onset, progressively worsening bloating mainly evening to morning with no Sx lunch to evening interestingly when she eats her biggest meals accompanied by lower abdominal cramping pain and separate constipation which she feels is not linked without any apparent complications in the setting of comorbidities including anxiety/depression on SSRI and obesity and FHx notable for pancreatic cancer (M, AC, Stage 4, passed away 58yo). She was told bloating was due to previous ovarian cyst rupture but unclear. There appears to be no link with sick contact, foreign travel, specific medication use, specific food intake, positional changes, bowel movements, stress or time of day and has not identified any clear precipitants or any alleviating or exacerbating features. She had HP breath test in 1/23 negative.  Patient has not had any other GI/PHB specific diagnostic w/u. She is on probiotics and has been on Miralax. Patient has not used any other Rx/OTC/CAM GI/PHB meds. Patient eats a balanced, healthy diet with one meal a day at lunch and notes no nutrient/element/mineral/vitamin deficiency or any food intolerances/allergies. She has tried fibers and avoided lactose/gluten. No other dietary changes were made. Patient denies any other upper/fore-to-midgut GI symptoms including upper abdominal pain, heartburn/pyrosis, indigestion, nausea, vomiting/emesis, coffee ground bleeding, hematemesis, globus sensation, dysphagia, odynophagia, chest pain, regurgitation, hiccups/singultus, excessive burping/eructation, early satiety, decreased appetite or any respiratory/ENT symptoms. Patient denies any other lower/mid-to-hindgut GI symptoms including anorectal pain/itching, incontinence, diarrhea, excessive flatulence, abnormal stool contents, hemorrhoids, fissures, fistulas, skin tags or hernias. Patient denies any hepatobiliary symptoms including jaundice, icterus, dark urine, clay stools, pruritus, easy bruising/bleeding, abdominal/leg swelling, rash or confusion. Patient denies any systemic symptoms including weight loss, fatigue, fevers, chills or night sweats. Below you will find my impression and plan as requested. Thank you for giving me the opportunity to participate in the care of your referred patient. Please contact me directly on my cell (214-908-4292) anytime if you have any questions. In good health, Alexander Mantas, MD.

abdominal pain, constipation and diarrhea, H. pylori +

Patient is Spanish-speaking only and history obtained through translator. 29-year-old male presents to clinic with midepigastric abdominal pain with associated nausea and vomiting, worsening postprandial. This is been escalating in intensity for the last 3 months. 2 months ago he was diagnosed with H. pylori and treated with amoxicillin, clarithromycin and PPI therapy. He did not feel like the antibiotics was beneficial and there was no follow-up breath test to evaluate for for eradication. He states that the pain is a pressure-like pain which is constant, worsening after eating with associated nausea. No overt GI bleeding, melena, hematochezia. An emergency room visit where an ultrasound revealed a normal-appearing gallbladder without stones.
At this time, I would like to continue with PPI therapy on a daily basis, trial antispasmodic. Will plan for EGD to evaluate for structural disorders taking biopsies for H. pylori, celiac. Will need to consider HIDA scan versus CT if symptoms do not improve.

Chief Complaint:
IBS/discuss getting colonoscopy, pt requested OV first
History of Present Illness:
Timothy Crosby is a 25 year old male patient w/ hx lower back pain due to congenital issue causing abnormal L5 (Bertolotti syndrome), prior Hodgekin Lymphoma with radiation to neck/upper chest, heart burn, depression/anxiety, and suspected IBS-M who is seen today for an initial visit for evaluation of IBS, hematochezia, and heartburn.
Pt reports abnormal bowel habits since childhood. Describes intermittent periods of severe constipation with passage of hard stools followed by periods of diarrhea with >6 bm daily. Each occur about 50-50. He was diagnosed with IBS-M by PCP and has multiple "Flares" yearly with severe pain. Recently, he is having diarrhea with up to 10 watery/loose BM daily and for last 3 months has noticed hematochezia and rectal pain. He was given anusol with some improvement. He has lost 10 lbs unintentionally. He reports trying multiple OTC laxatives in the past with no relief (Miralax, mag citrate, bisacodyl). He is currently not on any laxatives. No prior colonoscopy.
He also has significant daily heart burn and epigastric pain. He is taking approx 800mg of advil 4x daily for the last 6-7 years for his back pain in addition to implanted nerve stimulator. He reports no prior improvement with PPI, currently not on reflux therapy. No dysphagia. He reports EGD as a teenager showed possible barrett's esophagus and damage from reflux- no follow-up EGD after.

25M with prior Hodgkin Lymphoma s/p XRT to neck/upper chest, GERD with remote EGD showing possible barrett's, and longstanding altered bowel habits with suspected IBS-M. Of note, taking >2400mg ibuprofen daily for >5 years and has nerve compression/issues at L5 related to congenital spine syndrome.
Given his significant heart burn, epigastric pain, possible prior history of Barrett's, and epigastric pain, we will arrange EGD for further evaluation.

Chief Complaint:
Diarrhea
History of Present Illness:
Henry Ellis is a 47 year old male who is seen today for a first visit.
47-year-old male presents with chronic intermittent diarrhea, excessive flatulence, and mild fecal incontinence for approximately 18 months, which began after a severe bout of diarrhea (20 episodes in 48 hours) during a 4-week trip to South America. Patient reports episodic symptoms occurring approximately once weekly, characterized by a day of severe gas, bloating, and aggressive flatulence that is occasionally accompanied by small amounts of fecal leakage. He describes having to urgently go to the bathroom up to a dozen times daily due to fear of incontinence. Two weeks ago, he experienced an acute flare with 20 cases of diarrhea in a 48-hour period. This morning, he reports using the toilet four times before his appointment and noted some blood in his stool, which he attributes to rectal irritation from frequent bowel movements rather than frank blood.
Previous treatments have included a 7-day course of Levaquin and a 7-day course of Flagyl, neither of which resolved his symptoms. Patient has also attempted dietary modifications including gluten-free and lactose-free diets without improvement. He tried probiotics for three months from a specific manufacturer but did not notice any significant benefit. He has also been using a nutritional shake recently in an attempt to settle his symptoms. He has not tried any gas-reducing medications (gasx).
Patient reports an increase in appetite over and has experienced weight gain rather than loss. He continues to take Pantoprazole daily for management of GERD associated with a hiatal hernia, which was diagnosed in 2019 along with an esophageal ring that required dilation. He reports no current swallowing difficulties since the dilation procedure.
Recent labs show mildly elevated ALT (74) and cholesterol. Patient consumes approximately one alcoholic drink daily, sometimes more.

AbdusMolla is a 68 year oldmale patient who is seen today for an initial visit. Accompanied today by wife and daughter.
Chronic reflux for which he takes pantoprazole with moderate relief. Recent issues with epigastric pain, nausea.  Chronic issues with constipation.  Does not drink much water or fiber.

1. GERD
-plan for cardiac clearance, then  EGD to further evaluate abdominal pain/GERD
-pantoprazole 40 mg daily. GERD diet
2. Colon cancer screening
-plan for colonoscopy at same time as EGD
3. Chronic constipation
-increase water intake (goal 64 oz/daily) and fiber (goal 25-30g/daily)
-Improve blood glucose (last A1c is 9.7) as suboptimal blood glucose can adversely affect GI motility
-start  linzess 145 mcg daily to treat chronic constipation.  Samples given in clinic today

Chief Complaint:
bloating, altered bowel habits, diarrhea
History of Present Illness:
This is a 62-year-old female patient here to see me for chronic abdominal bloating and pain, which has been ongoing since 2012.
The patient reports significant abdominal bloating and pain, localized to the lower abdomen. These symptoms have been persistent since 2012. She denies any specific upper gastrointestinal symptoms such as heartburn, reflux, nausea, vomiting, or dysphagia. There is no mention of a change in bowel habits, constipation, diarrhea, blood in the stool, or rectal bleeding. She has had multiple emergency department visits for these symptoms, where investigations including abdominal X-rays and endoscopy were reportedly normal.
The only medication mentioned is metformin, which she has been taking for years. The onset of her symptoms does not correlate with the initiation of this medication.
Her pertinent past surgical history includes an intestinal perforation in 2012, which she believes was secondary to diverticulitis. This was initially managed medically without success, leading to a partial intestinal resection and a temporary colostomy for 6 months, after which she underwent a reversal procedure. Her chronic symptoms began after these surgical interventions. She had an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy approximately 5 years ago, which were normal. She has a family history of stomach cancer in a sister.

Diagnoses:
Bloating (abdominal)
Altered bowel habits
Diarrhea (c)
Assessment:
1. Chronic abdominal pain, diarrhea and bloating: The symptoms are most likely secondary to post-surgical adhesions. The history of intestinal perforation, peritonitis, and subsequent surgeries (colostomy and reversal) has likely resulted in scar tissue formation. This scar tissue can restrict the normal movement and distension of the bowel, leading to pain when gas is present, as it stretches the bowel wall and the surrounding adhesions. Other potential causes for her symptoms are being considered, including small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO), which can occur in the setting of altered bowel motility and anatomy post-surgically. While less likely given her previous negative evaluations, inflammatory bowel disease and celiac disease will also be formally ruled out via laboratory testing. Malignancy is very low on the differential given her normal imaging and endoscopic procedures, including a normal EGD and colonoscopy 5 years ago.
Plan:
- To investigate for SIBO, a breath test kit will be sent to the patient's home for completion.
- Labs ordered as below. The labs will assess for systemic inflammation and celiac disease.
- Follow-up will be scheduled to discuss the results of the breath test and laboratory studies to guide further management.
The patient has verbally consented to the use of a virtual scribe.
Plan:
Gastrointestinal Pathogen / GPP (QDx and Genesis)
Fecal calprotectin
Fecal elastase
Celiac Ab profile: tTg IgG/IgA, DGP IgG/IgA, total IgA
C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
SIBO (Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth Test) Trio smart/Commonwealth Diagnostics - lactulose - 91065
Additional Notes:
After Visit Summary:
- Your visit today was for long-term abdominal bloating and pain. We discussed that these symptoms are likely related to scar tissue from your past surgeries in 2012.
- We will do some further testing to look for other possible causes. We will be checking some blood work today. We are also sending a breath test kit to your home to check for a condition called small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO).
- Please complete the blood tests today. The lab is here in the building. You do not need to be fasting for these tests.
- For the breath test, the kit will be mailed to you. Instructions are included. After you complete the test, you will mail it back using the provided FedEx packaging.
- We will see you back in the office to review all the results and create a treatment plan.
- Do not start taking any probiotics until after you have completed the breath test.

Diagnosis:
Gastroparesis
Early satiety
Change in bowel habits (c)
Chronic idiopathic constipation
Personal history of colonic polyps
Assessment:
1. Moderate Gastroparesis
- Assessment: Delayed gastric emptying confirmed on scintigraphy. Correlates with endoscopic findings of retained food. Symptoms include bloating and constipation.
- Medical treatment planned: Discussed Reglan (metoclopramide) for acute symptom flares. To be used PRN. No daily medication planned now.
- Lifestyle modifications: Continue with dietary changes. Eat lighter diet if symptoms flare. Eat evening meal earlier. Adjust Miralax dose as needed to maintain regular BMs without diarrhea. Can use half-doses.
- Investigations planned: Discussed potential future interventions if symptoms worsen: EGD with Botox injection to pylorus, or surgical myotomy.
- Follow-up appointments: F/U in 1 year. To return sooner if symptoms progress.
2. Altered Bowel Habits (Constipation/Diarrhea)
- Assessment: Likely related to underlying dysmotility/gastroparesis.
- Medical treatment planned: Continue Miralax, titrating dose to effect. Discussed prescription medications for constipation if it worsens, but will remain conservative for now.
Additional Notes:
- Patient education on gastroparesis provided. Visited recommended educational website.
- Instructions for symptom monitoring: Advised to seek care if symptoms progress. Advised to de-escalate diet (e.g., liquids, low-fiber) during flares.
- Addressed concern regarding next colonoscopy. Recommended in 5 years, health permitting, per Dr. Fajardo's letter. Will re-evaluate need closer to the time.
Plan:
Follow-up office visit in 1 year
Patient counseled on best practices for gastroparesis
Follow-up with PCP
Call office with any questions or concerns.

Assessment:
Ms. Holland is a 28 y/o male with no PMH here for GI evaluation.
RIGHT LOWER QUADRANT PAIN, BLOATING, EARLY, IBS-C -
- RLQ pain began 2 weeks after she ate very "rich food" with her Grandmother -> seen at PFM ER on 9/9/25 with neg workup including labs, neg Abd US (nl GB) & neg CT a/p.
- had to lower to 1 meal a day b/c if she eats dinner, she throws up.
- increasing to 2 meals a day causes RLQ pain flare along with nausea & fullness in epig area & chest.
- also, complains of constipation & only has a BM if she takes '3 dulcolax' daily with incomplete evacuation
- hx of colonoscopy at age 12 & recalls being dx'd with IBS.
*Suspect IBS-C although unclear why it only began 2 weeks ago.
- advised a mini-cleanout with MOM or 1/2 bottle mag citrate tonight followed by Linzess trial - samples of 72 & 145 mcg given.
- If no relief with Linzess, can try other prescription meds for constipation including Trulance, Motegrity, Amitiza & Ibsrela also.
- if symptoms persist, can consider egd/colon next.
- will monitor closely.
FOLLOW-UP - in 3.5 wks with NP/PA.
Plan:
Do a mini-cleanout with Milk of magnesia (1-2 tablespoons) or 1/2 bottle of mag citrate. Then, begin maintenance bowel regimen as instructed the next day.
Start Linzess samples - 145 or 72 mcg - take 1 tablet daily on empty stomach. Ok to eat or drink in 30 mins. Let us know which dose works & we'll call in 90d supply
If even the lowest Linzess causes diarrhea, can just switch to Miralax 1/2-1 capful at bedtime & titrate as needed.
Follow-up office visit in 3 weeks with NP/PA

Chief Complaint:
Pt is here for procedure f/u
History of Present Illness:
Donna Patrick is a 78 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Patient is here for follow-up after having an upper GI endoscopy done. This was done for her complaints of dysphagia and underlying hiatal hernia. On EGD she was found to have a 6 cm hiatal hernia and dilatation of the distal esophagus/stricture was done. She feels that her swallowing has improved but is extremely concerned about her having fundic land polyps and states has been laying off of PPI. She has stopped PPI in the past also.
In terms of her constipation she states that she was unable to get lubiprostone from a Walmart pharmacy because of the cost. She has been taking magnesium with improvement of her symptoms.
She also has a known history of a pancreatic cyst which has been stable. Repeat MRI is pending in December but she is not sure if she wants to do this as she feels that she may not want to do surgery in future for the pancreatic cyst, if needed
8/8/25
Donna Patrick is a 78 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Patient here for GI consultation for complaints of having difficulty with swallowing. Patient states that sometimes she feels that the food gets stuck in the retrosternal area and sometimes she points to her lower sternum. On questioning she states this happens with both solids and liquids. Patient has known history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and a hiatal hernia and has been taking rabeprazole every day. On her last endoscopy she was found to have a 5 cm hiatal hernia and was suspected to have significant esophageal dysmotility. Patient denies any weight loss at this point.
She also states that her constipation has not improved but she still continues to struggle. She does use MiraLAX but finds it hard as she is to mix it with water or drink. She has been taking stool softeners every day without relief. She has known underlying constipation predominant IBS.
Patient also underwent an MRI of her pancreatic cyst repeat MRI shows a stable cyst in the neck of the pancreas measuring 1.1 cm x 0.5 cm. Findings are consistent with a sidebranch IPMN. Main pancreatic duct was normal. CBD was reported 10 mm but patient is status postcholecystectomy.
10/16/24
Donna Patrick is a 77 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Patient is here for a GI clinic visit as she had undergone a CT of the abdomen pelvis for renal stones on which she was found to have possibly a cyst in the pancreas. She subsequently underwent an MRI of the pancreas on which she was found to have 2 separate cysts. The largest cyst was measuring up to 1.5 cm x 7mm with mild lobulation and possibly an internal septation. No mural nodule was seen. No complication was seen with the pancreatic duct. The main pancreatic duct itself was not dilated. Another small 6 mm x 4mm cyst was seen inferior to the pancreatic head which possibly is communicating with the main pancreatic duct. On questioning patient does not have any epigastric pain at this point. There are no pancreatic symptoms. No prior known history of pancreatitis. Interestingly her CT done in 2022 had not reported any cyst in the pancreas.
Patient has known history of chronic heartburn for which she takes rabeprazole. Her main issue seems to be related to her having a lot of gas. Patient states that she has been working to lose weight and has lost over 20 pounds in the last 1 year. She has been eating very healthy.
She is known to have history of chronic right lower quadrant pain. A colonoscopy done in 2021 did not show any evidence of ileitis or colitis. CAT scans and never shown any evidence of right lower quadrant disease.:
7/19/23
Donna Patrick  is a 76 year old   female  who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Patient is here for a clinic follow-up and has multitude of complaints which she says that she has been having a lot of belching and feels very gassy, has been having a lot of flatulence. Patient is known to have history of gastroesophageal reflux and a hiatal hernia, is drinking carbonated water weight in front of me. States that she does need to drink carbonated water so that she is able to burp out her excessive gas. Patient has been taking omeprazole 20 mg every day. Patient for her abdominal bloating was told to go use a low FODMAP diet, but now blames the diet for her 20 pound weight gain. She is a history of chronic right lower quadrant pain which is some correlation with constipation. Patient states that when she uses MiraLAX she feels better with pain, though uses MiraLAX only one she is severely constipated which leads to subsequent diarrhea.
11/9/22
Donna Patrick  is a 75 year old   female  who is seen today for a follow-up visit.Patient had been seen around one year ago.  She continues to have chronic right hip pain which she feels also sometimes in the front. Patient had undergone a CT in June 2022, ordered by Urology.  This was a noncontrast CT.  No significant changes were seen as compared to her CT done late last year.  She does have underlying hiatal hernia and colonic diverticulosis.A colonoscopy done last year had shown diverticular disease without any strictures.
Patient states today that pantoprazole is not strong enough for her and she continues to reflux symptoms.  Other options were PPS were given and she states she has used them all.  It seems that she continues to drink at least 3-4 cups of caffeine every day and states she likes doing that and would like to continue with that.  Patient also likely has constipation predominant IBS and could not afford Linzess.  I had recommended her to use MiraLAX on a routine basis which she has not done so far.  She said she takes Colace, seems reluctant to use MiraLAX regularly.
11/17/21
Donna Patrick  is a 74 year old   female  who is seen today for a follow-up visit.Patient says that she recently was diagnosed to have osteoporosis and does not want to take biphosphonate's because of for GI issues. Dysphagia: I suspect patient's dysphagia is most likely due to esophageal dysmotility s/p  EGD with dilatation.Patient did feel improvement of her symptoms after dilatation. In terms of her esophageal dysmotility
I did discuss with her about making dietary changes and especially avoiding ice cold drinks or hot beverages, Patient should stay on PPI BID
Specially considering her large hiatal hernia and esophageal stricture formation.
I did explain that fundic gland polyps do not have any cancer potential even with use of PPI
Pancreatic cyst:
Patient was found to have 2 separate cysts in the area of the pancreatic head On a prior MRI. Repeat MRI done now shows 1 cystic lesion in the area of the pancreatic neck measuring 1.1cm x 0.5 cm. Pancreatic duct is normal.. It is possible that this/these may be IPMNs, no prior episodes of pancreatitis in the last few years. Clinically she is asymptomatic. Considering incidental finding of cysts, possibly needs ongoing surveillance with MRIs in Dec this year

I have given her the option for surgery for hernia repair and antireflux surgery, reluctant though wants to talk to surgery
Patientrecommended to continue on PPI and split dosing
Bloating: Advised patient to use probiotics on a regular basis, can consider use of Beano. Avoidance of fermentable foods is most to limit gas formation, patient blames a low FODMAP diet for weight gain.
Irritable bowel syndrome: Constipation predominant, Still continues to be symptomatic. I will try to send  lubiprostone to mark cuban's pharmacy

History of gastroparesis. Had episode of bloating and lower abdominal discomfort.
Had a diagnosis of Crohn's in 2003 and had bowel surgeries including a ileocecal area. Has taken sulfasalazine and Remicade in past. The last dose of Remicade was 3 years ago. Now on Humira. Father had IBS but no known family history of inflammatory bowel disease. Son had colon polyps. Had colonoscopy is attempted in April 2017 but could not be completed because of difficult anatomy. Average bowel movements about 6-7 and now having about 4 bowel movements a day. On Puree diet since 2015.
Take Naproxen and Ibuprofen for headache. Has more abdominal pain after taking Ibuprofen.
Medical records reviewed. On Humira 40 mg subcutaneous every 2 weeks. On B12 injections. Last from December 11, 2017 showed hemoglobin 8.1, hematocrit 24.8 and MCV 80. WBC 11.6 and platelets 328. BUN and creatinine normal. Bicarbonate 31. Chloride 105. Osmolality 277.
CT scan of abdomen and pelvis on April 2018 showed dilation and ileum with a thick walled and a collapsed terminal ileum. Findings consistent with a high-grade partial small bowel obstruction. Dilated ileal loops made up to 6 cm. Extensive body wall anasarca. Moderate-sized bilateral pleural effusions. Fatty infiltration of liver. Gastric lap band in place.
5.17.2018
Colonoscopy on April 2018 no diverticulosis sigmoid colon, stricture at the ileocecal valve and erythematous friable nodular mucosa and cecum.
Surgical pathology from April 2018 showed no cysts and terminal ileum and a fistula formation with extensive fibrosis. No evidence of dysplasia or malignancy. 6 lymph nodes were negative for malignancy.
Had episode of black stool 3-4 weeks ago. Otherwise feeling much better now. Have lost about 10 pounds since surgery. Good appetite. The bloating has improved. Still has excessive flatulence. Mild lower abdominal pain at area of surgery. Had a 34 cm of small bowel resection.
On Humira now ( Every 2 weeks 40 mg). Also BudesonideER 3 mg 3 tab/day.
July 5,2018
EGD on June 2018 showed a patulous lower esophageal sphincter, gastritis. AVM in the duodenum treated with argon plasma coagulation. Pathology showed mild chronic gastritis and negative for Helicobacter pylori.
Ultrasound of abdomen June 2019 showed fatty liver but no gallstones.
EGD in October 2020 showed mild gastritis and a few gastric erosions with dried Hematin material.
Colonoscopy showed multiple neoterminal ileum ulcers. Ulcers also seen at the ileocolonic anastomosis. No stricture. Few ulcers seen in ascending colon. Perianal skin tag. Internal hemorrhoids grade 2.
Pathology-mild chronic gastritis. Chronic active colitis with ulceration seen on ileocolonic anastomosis biopsies. Normal random colon biopsies.
Labs October 2022â€“WBC 14.9. Normal hemoglobin and hematocrit. Normal LFT. Negative QuantiFERON-TB test. Hep B surface antigen negative. CRP 27.
Labs June 2024 hemoglobin 11.8, hematocrit 36.9, MCV 88. Normal liver enzymes. Negative TB test. ESR 18. CRP 13. Hep B surface antigen negative.
Stool cultures negative.
â€“ C. difficile negative.
Fecal calprotectin 613. Stool WBC negative.
Colonoscopy August 2024 external hemorrhoids, skin tag. Postsurgical changes in the ascending colon. Unremarkable endoscopic appearance of colon mucosa. Internal hemorrhoids. Repeat exam in 3 years. Chronic inflammation at site of anastomosis. Diffuse chronic active colitis seen on random colon biopsies. No granulomas. No dysplasia.
Hospitalized August 2025 with a right lower quadrant abdominal pain and partial small bowel obstruction. Patient had NG tube with low intermittent wall suction. CT scan showed partial colectomy. Severely inflamed small bowel segment adjacent to anastomotic suture about 11 cm in length with luminal narrowing. Upstream small bowel dilation. Bile duct dilation seen. Patient was treated with IV steroids.

- Presentation for follow-up regarding gastrointestinal issues, specifically abdominal pain that has returned despite prednisone therapy.
- Current pain level is reported as 2. A bulge below the anastomosis is noted, which produces a sensation when pressed and pops up when sitting. This is perceived as a problem area. Another area of concern involves abdominal spasms experienced during eating or certain positions.
- History of significant scar tissue in the area of a previous surgery. The patient reports tremendous benefit from prednisone in reducing inflammation, but pain has recurred as the dosage is tapered.
- The patient continues to take Colestipol,, which has been highly effective in reducing the frequency of bowel movements and transforming them from explosive to productive. This medication is well-tolerated with no side effects reported.
- The patient notes that a significant amount of belly fat has been lost.
- No fever is present.
- The patient indicates having four teeth, necessitating a pureed diet, which is reported to be satisfactory.

Chief Complaint:
History of diverticulitis
History of Present Illness:
51-year-old lady who I saw for history of diverticulitis. She was evaluated at Methodist Dallas in May of this year for lower abdominal pain for the previous week and was diagnosed with what sounds like uncomplicated diverticulitis for which she was treated with an antibiotic. The pain subsided over the next week and has not recurred. She has not had any previous episode of diverticulitis. She has a bowel movement postprandially about 2-3 times a day. Chief Complaint:
GERD, atypical chest pain
History of Present Illness:
This is a 34-year-old patient here to see me for worsening symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease. He has a history of reflux for over eight years, with a prior upper endoscopy in 2018. He has been on pantoprazole 40 mg daily for approximately five years but reports his symptoms have been worsening despite this medication. His primary care provider recently prescribed esomeprazole, which he has not yet started.
He reports daily symptoms of constant burping and regurgitation of food particles, which he has to spit out. He denies any blood in the regurgitated material. Symptoms occur throughout the day and are not limited to specific times. He notes that even if he misses a meal, such as lunch, he will experience acid reflux symptoms despite having taken his pantoprazole in the morning. He denies any dysphagia or issues with swallowing. He does not experience nocturnal reflux symptoms that wake him from sleep. He reports experiencing intermittent, sharp, atypical chest pains, which he has had in the past and were evaluated by a cardiologist who attributed them to reflux. He also describes a sensation of bloating after taking his medication, which lasts for a while before fading. He reports that his gastrointestinal symptoms can trigger his anxiety, and vice-versa, creating a cycle.
He has been on pantoprazole 40 mg daily for about five years. His provider recently prescribed esomeprazole. He has previously tried a combination of pantoprazole 20 mg and famotidine, which provided no relief.
Past medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease and anxiety. He underwent an upper endoscopy in approximately 2018 due to reflux. He denies any complications from prior endoscopy or anesthesia. He has no known cardiac or pulmonary history other than the atypical chest pain evaluated and deemed non-cardiac.
He has made significant dietary modifications since the beginning of the year, reducing consumption of greasy foods and eating out only once a week instead of frequently. This has contributed to a weight loss from 300 lbs at the beginning of the year to a current weight of 273 lbs. He denies any family history of similar gastrointestinal problems. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Alcohol use was not discussed.

Atypical chest pain
Assessment:
1. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD): Symptoms are significant and refractory to a 5-year course of pantoprazole 40 mg daily. He experiences daily regurgitation, burping, and atypical chest pain despite medication. His symptoms have persisted despite positive lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and weight loss. The chronicity of his symptoms (8+ years) and inadequate response to a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) warrant further investigation. The plan is to repeat an upper endoscopy to evaluate for chronic changes such as a hiatal hernia, a lax lower esophageal sphincter, or Barrett's esophagus, and to rule out other pathology. The possibility of future surgical intervention, such as a LINX procedure or hiatal hernia repair, was discussed as a long-term management option if medical therapy remains suboptimal, given his young age.
Plan:
- An upper endoscopy (EGD) is planned to evaluate the esophagus and stomach. We will take biopsies to rule out infectious etiologies and evaluate for chronic changes.
- The risks and benefits, preparation, and procedural details were discussed and any questions were answered.
- The patient will stop taking pantoprazole and start esomeprazole as prescribed by his primary care provider.
- Follow-up will be scheduled after the procedure to discuss the findings and adjust the management plan accordingly.
The patient has verbally consented to the use of a virtual scribe.
Plan:
EGD with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43235
Risks and benefits statement: The procedure and its preparation, benefits, alternatives, and limitations were explained to the patient or legal guardian. The risks and potential complications including but not limited to perforation, bleeding, infection, missed lesion, aspiration and other complications of sedation were reviewed. The patient or legal guardian verbalized understanding and wishes to proceed.
Additional Notes:
After Visit Summary:
- Your visit today was for long-term acid reflux that is not getting better with your current medication, pantoprazole. Your symptoms include daily burping, food coming back up, and chest pain.
- We discussed that your symptoms are significant enough that we need to take a closer look with a camera test called an upper endoscopy (EGD). This will help us see if there is any damage to your esophagus from the acid or if there is another reason for your symptoms, like a hernia. We also discussed that depending on the findings, surgery might be an option in the future to provide a more permanent solution for your reflux.
- You should stop taking the pantoprazole.
- You should start taking the new medicine your doctor prescribed, esomeprazole. Please call your pharmacy to have it filled.
- We will schedule the EGD procedure. You will be able to pick a date that works for you. You will need someone to drive you home on the day of the procedure.

Chief Complaint:
dysphagia, screening for colon cancer
History of Present Illness:
This is a 62-year-old female patient of Dr. Coxsey with GERD previously under the care of Dr. Vallera and last seen by him on 12/1/22; she had a barium esophagogram around that time that was unremarkable. She has had similar complaints for 5-6 years. This does not effect her swallowing. She has this feeling all of the time. She has occasional reflux. She does not take any medications for acid reflux. She denies stress or anxiety. She had surgery on her vocal cords when she was a child.
She has a remote history of H pylori status post treatment.
EGD, 11/3/2021, Normal mucosa in the middle third of the esophagus. (Biopsy), Irregular margins in the gastroesophageal junction compatible with changes of chronic esophagitis and Erythema in the antrum and stomach body compatible with gastritis. (Biopsy, Biopsy). Mid esophageal biopsies normal. Gastric biopsies showed a mild chronic gastritis; H pylori negative. There was also focal intestinal metaplasia.
CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis 11/5/21 as follow-up to an abnormal ultrasound and MRI showed scattered hepatic angiomyolipomas. The bowel was described as normal.
She has not had a prior colonoscopy. Cologuard 11/19/21 was negative.
Labs 7/25/22 revealed a normal CBC other than a WBC 3.5 (L). CMP was normal.
Labs from 7/22/25 unremarkable
She is here to discuss dysphagia to solids and sometimes to liquids.

Chief Complaint:
Follow-up from recurrent admissions for anemia and GI bleeding
History of Present Illness:
-81-year-old who was transferred from an outside facility for anemia and black and tarry stools. I originally did the endoscopy and found he had several AVMs 1 in the stomach and 1 in the small bowel that I treated with APC. He responded to blood and iron and was eventually discharged. Within a week or 2 he presented back with symptomatic anemia with again drop in his hemoglobin and the passage of black stool. He was transferred back to Harris Southwest where one of my partners did a second endoscopy and retreated several AVMs. Since that time he has done well with only really 1 bowel movement since his discharge. He did see hematology who is planning on giving him iron transfusions. He also saw cardiology who thinks he may or may not need cardiac stents and/or other revascularization procedures plus he also might be a good candidate for a Watchman procedure which would allow him to get off of the Eliquis.

Long term use of anticoagulants (e)
Assessment:
-This is almost certainly a result of AVMs complicated by him starting Eliquis for his A-fib. Unfortunately his stroke risk is high enough that coming off the Eliquis is not a good option but he may be a candidate for the watchman. We have performed 2 endoscopies where several AVMs have been cauterized but I suspect that he has multiple more distal in his small bowel that have been bleeding resulting in his anemia and admissions. We need to do a capsule endoscopy to document that there is no other bleeding source in his GI tract as well as to document the presence of AVMs if they are there. He is not a good candidate for anything other than emergent endoscopy given his suspected coronary artery disease and thus would not recommend doing a colonoscopy at this time.
Plan:
Small bowel capsule endoscopy - 91110 Please give 1/2 dose of the miralax gatorade prep prior to the capsule study.

Chief Complaint:
Stomach / Abdominal Pain and Burning, Constipation
History of Present Illness:

Does have heartburn takes omeprazole for this and seems to control. Has also had chronic pain follows with pain specialist. Has not had egd or colonoscopy had cologuard last year and thinks may have been positive but he attributed to swallowing blood from his dental procedure. Has CHF and follows with cardiologist now Dr. Levin and has done well for several years on medication for control. Had swallow study which was normal he thinks and also had laryngoscopy with ENT and was reportedly normal.
6/13/25: 70 yo M w/ PMHx of reflux here in clinic for the above. Pt was previously recommended to have a EGD/colonoscopy for screening and dysphagia however this was not done. Per chart review, pt declined to schedule on 5/14/24. Pt seen today c/o stomach issues for the past few months. Reports constant abdominal pain/discomfort, worse when hungry, rated 6/10. Difficulty eating/drinking due to significant bloating, adding even water causes bloating, so he sips water to keep throat moist while minimizing symptoms. Denies any associated N/V. Bloating and muscle pain worsen SOB. Poor sleep, reporting about 3 hrs/night due to pain when his pain medications wear off. Continues to have dysphagia to solids more than liquids and states tilting head helps. On omeprazole 20 mg, controls reflux w/ occasional breakthrough. Reports change in bowel habits since abd pain onset, reporting few BMs/week, Bristol 1-4. Uses stool softeners PRN w/ moderate relief and takes MOM as needed. Takes daily ibuprofen for chronic shoulder pain for several years. Multiple recent ER visits w/ last at THK ED on 6/11/25 for abdominal pain, decreased BMs, SOB, and CP. ED workup unremarkable including abdominal US (6/11/25) showed hepatic steatosis, mild GB wall thickening, no stones. CTAP w/ contrast showed pericholecystic edema, bilateral pleural effusions, hepatic steatosis. Pt was recommended to f/u w/ PCP. Denies blood thinner, tobacco, or alcohol use. Notably, pt had positive Cologuard 2 yrs ago and has not had colonoscopy to further evaluate.
9/11/25: 70 yo M w/ PMHx of reflux, fatty liver, atrial fibrillation (Afib) (cardioversion in 12/2024 and 1/2025), and stent placement in 8/2025, presents for f/u. He has had increased SOB and fluid retention over the past several weeks, leading to multiple ER visits and hospitalizations, the most recent from 9/1-9/2. He was transferred from THK for evaluation of CP. Initial workup showed no acute ischemia. His sx were likely non-cardiac and he was referred to pain management for arthritis and pain medication adjustment. He reports seeing cardiology 2 days ago and was told his heart is stable.
He now reports persistent, severe abdominal pain described as constant, sharp, and burning, often feeling like a knife cutting him. The pain worsens when hungry or after eating, leading him to avoid food. It is sometimes so severe it affects his breathing and wakes him at night. He was visibly teary during the visit, distressed by the ongoing pain. Pain medications (morphine, fentanyl, hydrocodone) have provided minimal relief, w/ hydrocodone worsening his breathing and causing hypotension. He also reports new-onset N/V starting last week, w/ episodes triggered by food smells. Bloating occurs after every meal, and he experiences pain when wearing a belt. His bowel habits alternate between constipation and regular BMs, though he sometimes goes days w/o a BM. MOM prn has been helpful, having stools that are Bristol 1-6. Additionally, the patient requires supplemental oxygen due to SOB.

History of Present Illness:
Pt is a 26 yo male with PMH of autism who is nonverbal, Crohnâ€™s disease with stricture here for follow up after ER visit.
The most recent visit was in the past few days, with a prior visit in August. His mother, who is his primary caregiver, accompanies him as he is nonverbal with autism.
During the most recent emergency room visit at Methodist, lab work revealed an elevated white blood cell count, but no anemia. Liver function tests, kidney function, lipase, and urinalysis were all within normal limits. An abdominal X-ray was unremarkable. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was performed, which demonstrated fecalization of the terminal ileum with a dilated, stool-filled appearance, suggestive of slow transit. The report also noted possible terminal ileitis, though the appendix was normal. Following the visit, he was prescribed a three-day course of prednisone and Colace. The mother reports that leading up to this visit, he was exhibiting unusual lethargy, poor oral intake, and minimal fluid consumption. When prompted to show where it hurt, he would touch his side, and his blood pressure was noted to be elevated.
There is significant concern from his mother that his current biologic therapy, Renflexis, is not effective. She reports that he did not seem to have these problems when he was on Remicade. The switch from Remicade to the biosimilar was due to a change in insurance. She is interested in exploring options to switch back to Remicade, including self-pay options.
His mother reports his bowel movements have been variable. Recently, they were loose. She has been using Miralax but has tried to administer it every other day, noticing that his stools were very small and soft, and perhaps larger when Miralax was held. He sometimes appears to be straining or unable to fully evacuate. He was previously on pantoprazole 40 mg for suspected reflux due to tugging at shirt, which was decreased to 20 mg at the mother's request as she no longer observed the chest-related behaviors. She has been giving him two 20 mg tablets recently out of concern. He has not been tugging at his shirt lately.
His weight has trended down from 320 lbs to 302 lbs today. A previous FibroScan was reassuring, showing no evidence of fatty liver or fibrosis.

- CT scan done during ER visit showed fecalization of the TI with dilated stool-filled TI suggestive of slow transit and possible terminal ileitis. Normal appendix. CBC, CMP, and lipase were unremarkable. Pt was given prednisone 20 mg 3 tablets x 4d and Colace 100 mg BID x 10d but the pt did not start either medication
- Long-term therapy includes Renflexis infusions every 8 weeks, next infusion is on Saturday, 09/13/2025
- Stop Miralax and continue Renflexis infusions
- Reminded the patient's mother about the fecal calprotectin and CRP to evaluate the inflammatory status of the disease. Discussed that a colonoscopy should be considered as well since the last colonoscopy was in 2023 to evaluate disease progression.
- May consider changing therapy for Crohn's based on results of fecal calprotectin, CRP, and colonoscopy
- Start Linzess 145 mcg QD to address constipation better
2. Acid reflux
- Manages with pantoprazole 40 mg QD but patient's mother is unsure of the efficacy of the medication or if the pt is experiencing acid reflux due to his non-verbal state
- Pt would previously tug on his shirt which his mother interpreted as acid reflux
- Lifestyle and dietary modifications were reviewed, including avoiding spicy, fatty, acidic foods, caffeine, carbonation, and alcohol. Advised to elevate the head of the bed, eat smaller, more frequent meals, and avoid eating late at night (after 8 p.m.)
- Will schedule EGD with colonoscopy to assess for gastric and esophageal inflammation and if management with pantoprazole is necessary
- Advised to try pantoprazole 20 mg QD and see if the pt starts tugging on his shirt again. If he does, he may return to 40 mg dose daily
3. Fatty liver
- No evidence seen on Fibroscan in August
- Fibroscan showed F0-F1, suggesting minimal to no fibrosis., CAP value is consistent with no steatosis, S0
- Continue with lifestyle changes for fatty liver. Maintain a low-fat, low-carb diet

Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain
History of Present Illness:
Patient last seen July 10, 2025 for diffuse abdominal pain, fecal incontinence, reflux, nausea with vomiting and diarrhea. Patient had an EGD and colonoscopy showing only gastritis with benign biopsies, normal gastric bypass anatomy and a normal colonoscopy to the hepatic flexure. A Cologuard was ordered to rule out any lesions in the ascending colon and came back negative. Random biopsies were negative for microscopic colitis. She continued to have frequent bouts of nausea/vomiting and diarrhea. She is vomiting undigested food several hours after eating. Question whether she could be experiencing some gastroparesis. A gastric emptying study was ordered. As for the diarrhea stool studies were ordered to rule out infectious etiologies and EPI. She was given colestipol for suspected bile acid diarrhea. May also have SIBO or IBS-D. She was sent for anorectal manometry testing with Dr. Winston for fecal incontinence. Her PPI was switched to Voquezna for better coverage of her acid reflux symptoms. Patient has not yet had the gastric emptying study done. Stool testing came back negative for infectious etiologies. Pancreatic elastase came back at 290.
Patient was seen by Dr. Winston this afternoon he did some initial testing on her and found her to have a weak anal sphincter. She will have complete anorectal manometry testing soon. He suggested a possible spinal stimulator to help with her fecal incontinence. Patient states that she has her gastric emptying study scheduled on October 1. She says with the colestipol she is not having as much diarrhea but either her stools are very hard or there diarrhea. She has noted increased abdominal pain, cramping and gas in the last 2 weeks. She says that no matter what she eats she feels like she is "digesting rocks." Pain is in the upper abdomen rated up to an 8 out of 10. He will last until she is able to have a bowel movement. No fevers or chills. She notes some occasional blood in the stool when straining which she is not unusual for her. She has not had any recent abdominal imaging since May or June 2025. Patient states she was diagnosed with gastritis and she had normal labs. A total of 12 minutes were spent with the patient over the phone while provider present in the satellite office. No internet access available.

Chief Complaint:
GI bleed follow up/ ERCP follow up
History of Present Illness:
Joseph Hooter is a 63 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. He was recently hospitalized for acute blood loss anemia and underwent bidirectional endoscopy with no obvious etiology. Potential causes included diverticular hemorrhage as he did experience fairly copious bleeding in the days preceding this. He did receive transfusion and iron infusion thereafter and blood count is normalized. There were no other culprit abnormalities. He has undergone ERCP as well with stent removal and has no indwelling stents at this time. Hepatic enzymes are normal. He has no abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. He reports occasional difficulty swallowing, but mucosal examination recently was normal and he feels that this may have been in part related to previous chemotherapy administration.
He was diagnosed with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma in 2021 and underwent Whipple procedure 9/29/2021. Liver biopsy obtained at the time of surgery revealed moderate microvascular and macrovascular steatohepatitis with stage 3 fibrosis. Post operatively he underwent 12 cycles of chemotherapy planned every 2 weeks, which he finished in April 2022. During chemotherapy he had an increase in liver enzymes which were thought to be attributed to chemotherapy. Liver enzymes were elevated in cholestatic pattern and he was ultimately started on ursodiol 250 mg BID with consistent downtrend in ALP. Most recent ALP in December 2023 - 194. Most recent imaging was performed with oncologist and included MRI 2023, results are unavailable however imaging was reportedly unremarkable. Labs December 2023: Normal creatinine/GFR, bili 0.7, alk phos 194, AST 45, ALT 50, hemoglobin 12.7, hematocrit 37.6, platelets 111, AFP 2.7
EGD 2017: Probable mild peptic esophagitis status post biopsy. Otherwise widely patent esophagus: Distal esophageal biopsy showed eosinophilic count up to 25 per high-power field with mid esophageal biopsies notable for 0-2 eosinophils. Gastric biopsy showed focal complete intestinal metaplasia
Colonoscopy 2017: Normal
Fibroscan 2017: Severe hepatic steatosis and mild fibrosis, F1 to F2
CT scan 2016: Hepatic steatosis
Abdominal ultrasound 2016, hepatic steatosis
