Assessment:
Biliary obstruction-status post successful ERCP with metal stent placement. Hepatic enzymes have normalized. All stents have been removed. Will repeat labs in 3 months with consideration of further biliary intervention based on hepatic enzyme levels
Abnormal hepatic enzymes-resolved, likely sequelae of the biliary obstruction. These have normalized
Cirrhosis-May be related to either previous chemotherapy or perhaps underlying fatty liver disease. No overt complications of cirrhosis and imaging has shown no structural disease. There are no esophageal varices. Continue clinical follow-up every 3 to 6 months with imaging to be performed at those intervals given high risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.
History of pancreatic cancer-no evidence of radiographic recurrence
Anemia-Etiology for recent acute blood loss anemia is unclear, although the differential includes diverticular hemorrhage which appeared to have been self-limited or hemorrhoidal bleeding. I will also refer him to nutritionist as he has some questions regarding specifics regarding macronutrient supplementation

Chief Complaint:
Screening colonoscopy
History of Present Illness:
52 yo woman with a history of HLD referred for a screening colonoscopy. She has never had a colonoscopy. She reports she had a negative cologuard 2 years ago.
She has had some lower left abdominal pain, like someone is stabbing a knife in her abdomen. This has resolved and happened about three weeks ago. Heating pad has helped with this. Pain was present for six weeks and during this time she had intermittent issues with nausea. She saw her OBGYN and PCP and everything looked ok. She was told to follow up with GI.
She does not have a family history of colon cancer. No unintentional weight loss. No acid reflux/heartburn. In the morning she does have coffee in the morning and after that she does have to clear her throat. GERD is more diet related. No difficulty swallowing. No blood in the stool. No change in bowel habits. She has 1-2 BMs a day which is normal for her. When she has greasy food, she has constipation.

nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation

Recent loss of appetite over the last 2-3mo.  Dysphagia in clavicular area.  Has been on omeprazole 20 daily for a long time.  Dr Saini gave her rx for zofran and dicyclomine.

Assessment:
79F w PMH HTN DM HLD hypothyroid breast CA s/p mastectomy/XRT referred for eval of R abd pain, N/V, loss of appetite.  Chronic RUQ/RLQ pain with extensive workup in the past and possibly a positional component.  We discussed that timing of her pain after her prior hysterectomy (for possible uterine malignancy?) suggests possible GYN or scar tissue etiology.  But given findings of gastritis on CT with loss of appetite and dysphagia I do think EGD would be reasonable, although benefit of repeat CT or SBFT likely low yield especially given chronicity.  Also discussed changing PPI and increasing dose.
- Pantoprazole 40 daily instead of omeprazole.
- EGD at NTGIC.
RTC prn based on above
Plan:
EGD with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43235
pantoprazole 40 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth once a day 30 min before breakfast

Diagnoses:
Left upper quadrant pain
Nausea
Bloating
Constipation
Assessment:
We will perform an upper endoscopy to assess for gastritis/duodenitis, peptic ulcer disease, gastric outlet obstruction, and additional etiologies of left upper quadrant pain associated with nausea and bloating. We may consider a gastric emptying study if endoscopy is unremarkable.
For constipation, she has been counseled on high fluid intake and fiber supplementation with Metamucil and osmotic laxatives such as Miralax. Other medications may be considered such as stimulant laxatives (such as Dulcolax), enemas or suppositories (in the setting of fecal impaction) or prescription medications such as Trulance, Amitiza, Linzess or Ibsrela if there is no improvement with fiber supplementation and osmotic laxative use.
Plan:
EGD with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43235
Gradual titration of fiber supplementation discussed (Benefiber, psyllium (Metamucil) or Citrucel - 1-2 heaped tablespoons daily with fluids.
Miralax titration recommended

Chief Complaint:
Establish care--transfer from outside GI provider
History of Present Illness:
Linda Petrikovic is a 80 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit.
The patient is here to establish care with Dr. Gutta, transferring from Dr. Gorrepati. She was initially evaluated at Azle Hospital earlier this year for severe diarrhea and underwent an extensive workup, including EGD and colonoscopy (03/2025) performed by Dr. Gorrepati. EGD revealed an esophageal ulcer. Colonoscopy revealed lymphocytic colitis. Recommended repeat EGD and she was started on budesonide but discontinued it due to adverse reactions and does not wish to restart this therapy. A recent repeat EGD (08/2025) to assess healing of the ulcer was normal with normal pathology as well.
About 3 weeks ago, she was evaluated by her PCP, who ordered stool studies and labs: Stool studies and labs both were normal. Patient was noted to have EPI from previous stool studies, though the patient was not aware of this and she is not on Creon or other pancreatic enzyme replacement.
She was prescribed Lomotil for 1 week by her PCP which significantly improved her diarrhea, but symptoms recur after completing the medication.
She was also recently evaluated by cardiologist Dr. Newman for new onset atrial fibrillation, who recommended starting Eliquis, but advised deferring until discussing with GI given her recent history of esophageal ulcer. She has not started Eliquis at this time. Currently, she reports 5-6 loose to watery stools per day, denies abdominal pain or rectal pain. Denies overt GI bleeding, denies upper GI symptoms including reflux, dyspepsia or dysphagia. Denies other GI alarm symptoms.

Assessment:
1. Chronic diarrhea: Lymphocytic colitisâ€“colonoscopy confirm lymphocytic colitis. Symptoms improved with Lomotil but recurred after discontinuation of budesonide not tolerated due to adverse effects. Stool studies and labs are negative for infection or other metabolic causes. Given budesonide intolerance, we can consider alternative therapies such as bismuth subsalicylate, loperamide. Avoid dairy products, fried food, spicy food, sugary foods/drinks.
2. Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency: Not currently on pancreatic enzyme therapy, stool studies from 06/2025 showed low fecal elastase. Trial of pancreatic enzymes replacement (Creon). If no improvement we can consider lomotil.
3. History of esophageal ulcer: Nonhealing, confirmed by recent normal EGD and biopsies. Continue standard reflux precautions.
4. Atrial fibrillation: Recently diagnosed; Eliquis recommended by cardiology but deferred due to prior ulcer. Coordinate with cardiology regarding anticoagulation and now that ulcer is healed.
5. GERD: Stable, GERD diet discussed in detail.
All questions answered.

Follow-up office visit in 6 weeks

Avoid fried food, dairy products, spicy food, mexican foods, raw vegetables, caffeine, tea, and add metamucil. Also we will start her on Creon given hx of EPI.

Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
History of Present Illness:
Patient presents for evaluation of a several month history with lower mid and left lower quadrant abdominal pain associated with urinary symptoms of difficulty voiding. He states that this started rather abruptly earlier this year and he went to a walk-in clinic. Laboratory testing was done and according to the patient was all normal. A CT scan of the abdomen pelvis was also done and reportedly was normal. I do not have a copy of those records and we will request them. Patient states that the doctor recommended that he see a urologist and was seen by Dr. Matthew Willner. Patient states he was started on some medication that he took for couple months and his symptoms resolved. He does not know the name of the medication but his pain resolved for a few months until recently it has recurred. Patient is unable to identify any aggravating or relieving factors. He states that he does urinate a lot but he has no pain or difficulty urinating or moving his bowels. He has not seen any blood or cloudy urine. Patient states his weight has been stable. He has no known family history of GI problems including colon cancer pancreatitis or ulcer disease. He specifically states that the pain is down low beneath the umbilicus and he has no upper GI symptoms such as reflux epigastric pain or right upper quadrant pain.

Epigastric discomfort, history of H. pylori: Patient has tested negative for H. pylori recently and was off of all antibiotics and antacid medications in preparation for the test. She is concerned primarily with her family history of esophageal cancer. She does not have any red flag symptoms including dysphagia, unexpected weight loss, melena which is very reassuring. Discussed with her that we could just try omeprazole for 1 month course as gastritis/mild esophagitis is the likely cause of her symptoms but patient is also concerned. Offered EGD to take a look down given her family history and ensure no other significant pathology.
â€“ EGD for further evaluation
â€“ If patient does not want to pursue EGD, can use omeprazole as needed
â€“ Can also use Tums/Pepcid as neededâ€“recommendations given
Follow-up in office as needed
Plan:
EGD with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43235

Chief Complaint:
Abdominal Pain, Constipation, Hemorrhoids
History of Present Illness:
9/8/25
This is a 38-year-old man seen today in consultation for abdominal pain, constipation, and hemorrhoids. Consent was obtained for recording and use of AI scribe software. The patient reports experiencing right upper and right lower quadrant abdominal pain. A CT scan conducted at Medical City Plano revealed gallstones and constipation. The patient has never undergone endoscopy or colonoscopy in the past. He has experienced this abdominal pain for a couple of months, describing it as a dull pain, with episodes persisting for a few days at a time. He noted the pain is less severe than a past kidney stone, rating it a 2 or 3 out of 10 in intensity. There is no associated nausea. The patient sometimes associates the pain with bowel movements, experiencing a sensation of incomplete evacuation. He also reports a history of hemorrhoids for about three years, with occasional bleeding, particularly after prolonged sitting.
His constipation is characterized by infrequent bowel movements and incomplete evacuation, despite the urge to defecate. He was prescribed Miralax, which provided some relief but was not completely effective. The patient does not report significant gas or bloating. He denies any significant change in weight or appetite, although he notes his appetite is generally low due to taking Zep-Bound (10 mg for nearly a year), which he stopped briefly to assess its impact on his symptoms.
There is no known family history of colon cancer or colon polyps. His liver function tests are reported as normal, and other recent lab results include elevated LDL cholesterol (138), triglycerides (147), low HDL (38), and low vitamin D (28). His complete metabolic profile, TSH, T4, free T4, T3, CBC, B12, and folate levels are within normal limits.
- CT scan at Medical City Plano showed gallstones and constipation.

The patient verbalized understanding of the procedures and its risks, and agrees to undergo testing. All questions were answered. Handout Given.
- Initiate a high-fiber diet. I would like the patient to increase fluid intake to at least 60 oz of fluid daily if not more. I would also like the patient to start a chewable fiber supplement 5-10 g daily.
- Continue Miralax, considering either a double dose or twice daily dosing to improve bowel movements.
- Consider an ultrasound of the gallbladder to better assess the size and number of gallstones.  I will place a recall to check sonogram in six months
- Discuss with the patient the option of surgical consultation with Dr. London for potential future management of gallstones if symptomatic,  or if he has a gallstone greater than 2 cm.
- Recommend vitamin D supplementation to address the low vitamin D level.
- Monitor and manage cholesterol levels through diet and possibly medication, if necessary.
-  consider treatment with hemorrhoid banding for his hemorrhoids to follow, unfortunately Cigna does not appropriately cover the Hemwell procedure indication not be performed at the time of colonoscopy. Chief Complaint:
Here to establish GI care, Per Pt,  He was Dx with e coli and was hospitalized for 11 days. Pt was also Dx with colitis. Pt still c/o abd pain, bloating and gas
History of Present Illness:
Thomas Mitchell is a 73 year old  male patient who is seen at the request of Swatee Mohapatra for a consultation/initial visit.  He had a recent history of colitis and E. Coli and HUS.   He went to the ER on 8/17 and was started on an amoxicillin abx.  He went to the PCP, and lab work showed acute kidney renal issues.  He was then sent back to the hospital, and he was started on 4 different IV abx.  The next day, they stopped all abx.  His Cr was 4.8.  He was monitored for the next 11 days and given fluids.  No dialysis.
Most recent labs showed Cr 1.3.  Sodium is normal.  Hgb 11.7 (previously at 10).  CT scan on 8/17 showed a moderate wall thickening of the transverse, descending, sigmoid colon.  On 8/29, CT scan showed diffuse wall thickening of the descending, sigmoid and upper rectum.  The E. coli toxin was found in his stool.
Of note, wife had diarrhea on 8/15, and her symptoms resolved after a day.  He then got symptoms of diarrhea 1-2 days later.  He then had blood in his stools.  That was also what prompted him to go to the hospital.  She was sick on 8/13, and he got sick the next day or two.  He was not having a fever, but he did have some chills.   He has not had a colonoscopy done, but he has done a Cologuard most recently done in 2024.  The cologuard tests have been negative.
He has always been very regular with his BMs.  He is slowly getting better.  When he returned from the hospital, and it was painful.  The stools have been better - they are stolid and light brown in color.  He has been careful with his diet. He is not on fiber right now.  He is eating bland overall.  He started probiotics after coming home from the hospital.
Family Hx - no colon cancer or polyps; no stomach cancer; no IBD

Chief Complaint:
np abd pain, bloating, Gerd
History of Present Illness:
Patient presenting with complaints of epigastric pain. He says he has had dyspepsia for quite some time now but usually if it flares up and responds well to a GI cocktail. In June 2025 he had some severe symptoms while he was in Maryland which caused him to seek care at an emergency center there. He had a CT abdomen pelvis without contrast which showed no acute findings. The UA was negative for infection but did note a small amount of blood. LFTs were normal. Kidney kidney function electrolytes were normal. White blood cell count was mildly elevated at 12.8. Hemoglobin was normal at 15.4 and platelet count was 203. Patient was placed on Levsin and pantoprazole which he states did help. He did receive a GI cocktail at that visits but states that it did not work as well as it had on prior occasions. Patient's symptoms returned while later while in Louisiana after he had drinks of alcohol the night before. He states that he was able to control the symptoms at home and did not require another ER evaluation. Symptoms had been improving while on PPI and Levsin but he ran out of the medication and is having a recurrence of symptoms on a daily basis. He describes feeling bloated and heaviness in the lower abdomen along with pain in the epigastric region. There is no changes in bowel movements or rectal bleeding. No melena or hematochezia. No frequent NSAID use. No prior endoscopy.

Assessment:
Patient with ongoing epigastric pain improved with PPI therapy and GI cocktail. Workup in the ER in July was unremarkable. Will order an endoscopy for further evaluation and to rule out H. pylori gastritis, gastroparesis, peptic ulcer disease and malignancy. Will refill his omeprazole 40 mg once to twice a day and add hyoscyamine as well. Further recommendations pending results. See full plan below.
Plan:
EGD at hospital with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA - 43235
Follow-up in office two weeks after procedure
Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
omeprazole 40 mg Take 1 capsule by mouth once to twice a day, 30 minutes before the first meal of the day
hyoscyamine sulfate 0.125 mg take 1 tablet every 4-6 hours as needed for abdominal pain
